title: Born to Lead: The Pan Mabur Leadership Heritage
summary: How leadership has been passed from Monykuer Mabur to modern times...
content:
Leadership is not merely a role in Pan Mabur—it is a legacy. From the days of cattle herding to today's administrative duties, the spirit of governance has always been embedded in the family’s DNA. Monykuer Mabur was revered as a voice of justice and negotiation, often settling disputes from the cattle camps and in Duk Padiet with wisdom beyond his time.
His son, Manyok Monykuer Mabur, went further, rising to the rank of paramount chief—a position of great influence that spanned the entire Duk County. Under his stewardship, community affairs were structured, boundaries respected, and the rule of law embraced. He was succeeded by others like Chief Tiop Par Monykuer, Chief Deng Malual Mabur,Chief Deng Mathiang Mabur, and eventually Deng Mabur Malual, who now serves as the paramount chief of Duk County.
This continuity in leadership illustrates a deeply entrenched respect for governance, fairness, and community service values still evident among the younger generation stepping into administrative and advisory roles in South Sudan.

title: Dancing Through Time: Cultural Pride in Pan Mabur
summary: Dinka dance, cattle identity, and traditional values of Pan Mabur.
content:
The heartbeat of Pan Mabur is its culture—an elegant blend of song, dance, and symbolism. At the center of this is the Dinka dance, or Loor, a graceful performance that honors cattle, strength, and communal joy. With rhythmic drumming and flowing movements, dancers mimic the horns of bulls—an image of power and honor.
Cultural identity is also expressed through body art. Men once bore six lines on their foreheads, marks of bravery and initiation into adulthood. Women had their lower teeth removed, a sign of beauty and cultural conformity. Though these practices are less common today, they remain respected symbols of heritage.
The traditional home is a circle of respect—women managing the inner workings while men guide the outer affairs. This division is not restrictive but complementary, embodying balance and dignity in every household.

title: From Grass to Greatness: The Rise of Education in Pan Mabur
summary: How education and legacy shaped Pan Mabur’s progress.
content:
Once famed for vast cattle herds and fertile gardens, the Pan Mabur community embraced a new chapter in its story with the rise of formal education. Ambassador and General Mathiang Malual Mabur, the first in the family to attend school, became a beacon of transformation. He returned not just with a certificate, but with a dream—to educate the next generation.
His dream bore fruit. Today, over 90% of his descendants have completed at least Senior 4, with many entering university and professional roles in medicine, engineering, law, and civil service. Education has not only elevated the family’s status but also expanded their worldview.
Still grounded in their roots, many educated members return home to support local development—building schools, sponsoring children, and acting as role models.

title: Five Little Miracles, One Big Adventure: The Quintuplet Journey
summary: A family’s journey of love, resilience and belonging.
content:
The residents of Pan Mabur had never witnessed the joy of quintuplets until Adwai Malual welcomed five children—four girls and one boy—bringing immense happiness to their parents, Erjok Bullen and Adwai Mathiang, as well as their grandparents, Mathiang Malual Mabur and Nyanthon Wuor Abyei, and the entire communities of Hol and Bor. The excitement of this event led to grand celebrations and a sense of unity among everyone involved.
The quintuplets—Nyantueny Erjok, Deng Erjok, Athiei Erjok, Nyandeng Erjok, and Abyei Erjok—have been delightful to watch as they grew, embodying the traits of their parents under the care of their grandparents. As they reached school age, they approached this new chapter with eagerness and determination to pursue their newfound interest in education, and it’s noteworthy that they gave their all to their studies. They recently finished Year 11, achieving outstanding results, with Athiei Erjok Bullen earning recognition as a top achiever at their school, Royal International Schools, for scoring 5As in the recently concluded May/June 2025 IGCSE Examinations.
With dreams of pursuing their desired careers, their parents arranged for them to fly to the US, the country of their birth, to help realize those dreams. In that regard, their maternal aunt, Nyantet Mathiang Malual, travelled from the US to South Sudan, Juba to accompany the quintuplets to the United States, as they had been away for over a decade.
Upon their aunt’s arrival, a family prayer was organized at their grandfather's house to send off the quintuplets. The prayer was blessed by the presence of family members and in-laws, turning it into a moment of family reunion. It fills Mathiang Malual and Nyanthon Wuor, along with the entire Pan Mabur community, with joy to see their grandchildren chase their dreams and take this bold step towards pursuing their respective university careers. The Pan Mabur community can only pray and wish for their good health and success in their pursuits.

title: Royal Union: Sultan Joins Sultan in Love and Legacy
summary: A majestic bond between two royal families, a new chapter unfolds.
content:
In a traditional Dinka culture, the birth of a girl is always celebrated with joy and excitement throughout the community. This girl is raised and guided by her mother, father, aunts, and the entire community to grow into a respectable woman capable of managing her household when the time comes.
Ajok Deng Mathiang, daughter of a distinguished Sultan, Deng Mathiang Mabur of Pan Mabur and the broader Padiet Payam, was born in Duk and grew up in her family home in Duk Padiet, under the care of her father and mother (Atoch Lem Kuany) and her grandmother (Riak Biar), embodying their qualities. She is well-versed in the traditional lifestyle of Pan Mabur, having spent her childhood in Padiet.
Passionate about education and the new lifestyle compared to the previous nomadic existence, Ajok excelled in school and performed exceptionally in her South Sudan Certificate of Secondary Education (SSCSE). Although she faced delays due to tuition issues, she ultimately enrolled in a Law degree program at the University of Juba earlier this year.
Now of marrying age, Ajok found her new home in Pan Chengkuach, where there was great joy and happiness as her new found family prepared to welcome her into what could be her new life as a woman and as a mother to future generations. The two communities, Pan Chengkuach of Nyarweng, Payath—a respected home of sultans—and Pan Mabur of Hol, Angaach—renowned for their sultancy—came together for this momentous occasion. It was a significant honor for both communities to unite and establish what promises to be another enduring relationship, especially since Pan Mabur has a history of connections with Nyarweng.
The negotiations regarding the dowry were fruitful as both communities were earnestly dedicated to fostering their relationship with great respect, led by Chol Malual Mabur, the uncle of the bride, and Chengkuach Apam Chengkuach, the groom's uncle.
As a result, Pan Mabur graciously gave their daughter, Ajok Deng Mathiang, to Pan Chengkuach, and their union was solidified with a beautiful Aloththok ceremony at Garang Akok, where she received her Kuei dress—an important Duk women’s tradition for welcoming new brides into their homes. The event featured performances by several artists, including Arizona JJ and Slatine Pro, as well as attended by relatives, friends, and well-wishers. The Pan Mabur community extends their blessings to their daughter in her new home with Chengkuach Mabil Majok.
